subject: RE: [junit] help please?
msgSnippet: Hi Peter, Thanks a lot. But i have a doubt.Instead of fail in the below exampe we can also write AssertTrue(2
messageBody:
Hi Peter,
Thanks a lot.


But i have a doubt.Instead of fail in the below exampe we can also write

AssertTrue(2<1); //This will always fail.

So if the exception is not thrown from there then it will execute the above statement and it is going to report a failure

If this os ok what i am saying then what is is the need of a faile statement.

-Santu

Peterson Peixoto dos Santos <peter@...> wrote:
Hi Santu,

The fail method "fails" a test :-).
For what?, you might question...if we really want some line not to be reached, you might test this using a fail. Just like in:

public void testMyTestShouldThrowAnException() {
try {
obj.doSomethigThatThrowsAnException();
fail( "If we are at this line the excpetion was not thrown. So this test failed. JUnit must know that." );
} catch( AnException ex ) {
assertTrue( "If we are here, the exception was thrown, the test passed!", true );
}

Hope it helps!

Peter.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: santu nand [mailto:sknanda9@...]
> Sent: sexta-feira, 20 de agosto de 2004 01:25
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] help please?
>
>
>
> Hi,
>
> Can Anybody explain me what is the function of a fail method???
>
>
>
>
>
> Santanu
